label: HH1

text: SUDAN FLOODS
label: HH1

text: Credits
label: BODY

text: Cover photo: A portrait of Nykuoth Gatdet Bol, 42, outside her shop. She was displaced by floods from Guit County and now lives in the Bentiu IDP site D.
label: BODY

text: With cash assistance from CERF she started a business selling fish in Rubkona and Bentiu markets. She earns over 15,000SSP daily as profit, with which
label: BODY

text: she is able to pay her children’s school fees and meet her basic needs. Credit: OCHA/Sarah Waisna
label: BODY

text: Content:
label: BODY

text: Kate Katch, kate.katch@un.org
label: BODY

text: Innovating Anticipatory Action:
label: HH1

text: Lessons from the 2022 South
label: HH2

text: Sudan Floods
label: HH2

text: 1 OCHA, South Sudan Humanitarian Response Plan, 2022.
label: BODY

text: More reliable weather and vulnerability forecast-
label: BODY

text: ing means there is more opportunity than in past
label: BODY

text: decades to limit the humanitarian impact of certain
label: BODY

text: shocks. Taking action in advance of a crisis, before
label: BODY

text: either the shock or its peak impact, is known in the
label: BODY

text: humanitarian sector as anticipatory action. In es-
label: BODY

text: sence, anticipatory action makes acting the default
label: BODY

text: when risks, not needs, increase.
label: BODY

text: A predictive model or forecast that can be used to
label: BODY

text: trigger pre-agreed action plans and pre-arranged
label: BODY

text: finance is at the heart of anticipatory action. Ideally,
label: BODY

text: all these elements can be captured in a single
label: BODY

text: framework document that serves as a ‘rulebook’
label: BODY

text: for how anticipatory action is supposed to work
label: BODY

text: for a specific shock, in a specific context. But what
label: BODY

text: happens when there is insufficient forecast data
label: BODY

text: available, or the complex operating environment
label: BODY

text: in the country requires more time to prepare and
label: BODY

text: respond? Is it still possible for the humanitarian
label: BODY

text: community to be anticipatory and for the UN
label: BODY

text: Central Emergency Response Fund (CERF) to
label: BODY

text: release funds ahead of an impending crisis?
label: BODY

text: This was the situation facing South Sudan in 2022.
label: BODY

text: Through creative thinking and the decision to pilot
label: BODY

text: a new approach, the UN Office for the Coordination
label: BODY

text: of Humanitarian Affairs (OCHA) discovered the
label: BODY

text: answer is yes.
label: BODY

text: As Joyce Msuya, Assistant Secretary-General
label: BODY

text: for Humanitarian Affairs and Deputy Emergency
label: BODY

text: Relief Coordinator concluded, “The takeaway is
label: BODY

text: clear: anticipatory action works for climate-related
label: BODY

text: shocks in South Sudan, but also elsewhere, includ-
label: BODY

text: ing in Mozambique as I saw during my recent visit.
label: BODY

text: Government-OCHA collaboration on early warning,
label: BODY

text: combined with proactive community engagement,
label: BODY

text: saved lives and resources. This cost-effective, flexi-
label: BODY

text: ble approach helps minimize suffering.”
label: BODY

text: The challenge
label: BODY

text: At the beginning of 2022, communities across
label: BODY

text: South Sudan were suffering from three years of
label: BODY

text: unprecedented flooding. Floods had become a
label: BODY

text: year-round struggle, exacerbating an already dire
label: BODY

text: humanitarian situation, where more than two-thirds
label: BODY

text: of the population (almost 9 million people) needed
label: BODY

text: humanitarian assistance.1 Ongoing conflict and
label: BODY

text: instability in the country combined with the flooding
label: BODY

text: resulted in people being forced to leave their homes
label: BODY

text: time and time again.
label: BODY

text: In March 2022, OCHA explored the feasibility of
label: BODY

text: developing an Anticipatory Action Framework to
label: BODY

text: get ahead and mitigate the impact of severe floods.
label: BODY

text: OCHA’s Centre for Humanitarian Data explored the
label: BODY

text: available data and forecasts that could be used to
label: BODY

text: develop the trigger mechanism for a framework.
label: BODY

text: However, the predictive strength of forecasts usual-
label: BODY

text: ly used to provide information on future large-scale
label: BODY

text: flooding was limited for South Sudan.
label: BODY

text: S O U T H
label: H4

text: S U D A N
label: H4

text: E T H I O P I A
label: BODY

text: U G A N D A
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: REPUBLIC
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: OF THE CONGO
label: BODY

text: Bor
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Bentiu
label: BODY

text: Malakal
label: BODY

text: Sudd wetlands
label: BODY

text: Abyei
label: BODY

text: Data: FAO, Natural Earth, UNGIS. The boundaries and names shown and the designations used on this
label: BODY

text: map do not imply official endorsement or acceptance by the United Nations. Final boundary between the
label: BODY

text: Republic of Sudan and the Republic of South Sudan has not yet been determined. Final status of the Abyei
label: BODY

text: area is not yet determined.
label: BODY

text: 100km
label: BODY

text: The complex nature of the Sudd wetland’s ecosys-
label: BODY

text: tem meant that even where data was available and
label: BODY

text: trends could be observed, there was no clear corre-
label: BODY

text: lation with flooding. With no forecast available that
label: BODY

text: could provide a trigger for time-bound actions, an
label: BODY

text: Anticipatory Action Framework would not be viable.
label: BODY

text: There was another challenge. Even if the data was
label: BODY

text: available, traditional flood models typically forecast
label: BODY

text: only 1 or 2 weeks ahead. In a complex operating
label: BODY

text: environment like South Sudan, this may not provide
label: BODY

text: humanitarian actors and communities with enough
label: BODY

text: time to prepare. Many supply routes were already
label: BODY

text: submerged from the 2021 floods making preposi-
label: BODY

text: tioning supplies difficult, time consuming, and fully
label: BODY

text: dependent on air travel.
label: BODY

text: While the data infrastructure was inadequate to
label: BODY

text: create a predictive model or forecast, the Centre’s
label: BODY

text: analysis confirmed there was enough information
label: BODY

text: to indicate a significant flood was looming.
label: BODY

text: Typically, during the dry season, flood waters retreat
label: BODY

text: into the Nile and other river basins, drying out the
label: BODY

text: land and preparing for a new rainy season. Howev-
label: BODY

text: er, the flood waters from 2021 never receded and
label: BODY

text: remained above the highest levels observed in over
label: BODY

text: 20 years. Any new rains expected for 2022’s rainy
label: BODY

text: season would turn an already dire situation disas-
label: BODY

text: torous.
label: BODY

text: As Seth Caldwell from OCHA’s Centre for Human-
label: BODY

text: itarian Data observed, “The water levels were be-
label: BODY

text: yond anything seen, and that was before the 2022
label: BODY

text: rainy season had begun.”
label: BODY

text: In-country humanitarian and environmental experts
label: BODY

text: agreed that even with a normal rainy season, there
label: BODY

text: was extreme risk it would bring widespread floods
label: BODY

text: beyond the levels seen in 2021 and likely at or
label: BODY

text: beyond the scale of a 1 in 50-year event. Without
label: BODY

text: intervention, such an event could lead to drastic lev-
label: BODY

text: els of need for affected populations, many of whom
label: BODY

text: were already experiencing an extreme lack of food
label: BODY

text: and had exhausted all coping mechanisms.
label: BODY

text: 2 OCHA Mission Report to South Sudan, 2022.
label: BODY

text: Flooded area around the Sudd wetlands
label: BODY

text: in percentage (1998-2022)
label: BODY

text: South Sudan Sudd wetlands flood levels, January 1998 to April 2022,
label: BODY

text: using AER Floodscan data.
label: BODY

text: In Unity State, the flooding was expected to put
label: BODY

text: more than 320,000 people — over a third of whom
label: BODY

text: were already displaced — at risk of further displace-
label: BODY

text: ment, loss of livelihoods, disease outbreaks, food
label: BODY

text: insecurity and psychological distress.
label: BODY

text: Over 125,000 people living in the Bentiu internally
label: BODY

text: displaced persons (IDP) camp and in informal
label: BODY

text: camps in Bentiu town were particularly vulnerable
label: BODY

text: and at risk. Since 2021, the Bentiu area had been
label: BODY

text: surrounded by floodwater creating an island, cut
label: BODY

text: off from dry land and roads, protected by kilome-
label: BODY

text: ters of hurriedly constructed dykes. Roads to bring
label: BODY

text: relief items or evacuate people from flooded areas
label: BODY

text: were inundated. With very limited opportunity for
label: BODY

text: livelihoods and reduced access to aid, people were
label: BODY

text: extremely food insecure — at times resorting to
label: BODY

text: eating water lilies. Even a relatively small increase
label: BODY

text: in the water level or a dike breach would have cata-
label: BODY

text: strophic impacts.
label: BODY

text: Not only was the Bentiu IDP camp at risk of being
label: BODY

text: submerged, so was the site of Unity State’s human-
label: BODY

text: itarian operations. As an Inter-Cluster Coordination
label: BODY

text: Group Member in Bentiu said, “If we get a quarter
label: BODY

text: amount of the water that we currently have, we’re
label: BODY

text: all not going to be here.”2
label: BODY

text: The humanitarian community had merely a few
label: BODY

text: weeks, perhaps months, to prepare before the rainy
label: BODY

text: season began.
label: BODY

text: Flood extent, Bentiu town and IDP camp with airport strip in background
label: BODY

text: (June 2022). Credit: OCHA/Rawad El Zir
label: BODY

text: The solution
label: HH1

text: OCHA saw an opportunity. Pilot a lighter and nim-
label: BODY

text: bler approach to anticipatory action, where CERF
label: BODY

text: allocations can be provided earlier in countries
label: BODY

text: with protracted crises based on a high likelihood of
label: BODY

text: that country experiencing an additional shock that
label: BODY

text: would compound existing humanitarian needs.
label: BODY

text: Consequently, CERF did not need to wait for the
label: BODY

text: floods to destroy the homes and lives of people in
label: BODY

text: Bentiu. Instead, CERF pulled the response forward
label: BODY

text: by allocating US$15 million, complemented by an
label: BODY

text: additional $4 million from the South Sudan Human-
label: BODY

text: itarian Fund (SSHF) in May 2022, well ahead of the
label: BODY

text: 3 OCHA, CERF Press Release, 7 May 2022.
label: BODY

text: 4 South Sudan, public project tracker.
label: BODY

text: 5 E. Easton-Calabria, Acting in Advance of Flooding: Early Action in South Sudan, A Feinstein International Center Brief, 2023.
label: BODY

text: 2022 rainy season3 and months sooner than had
label: BODY

text: been the case in response to the 2020 and 2021
label: BODY

text: floods.
label: BODY

text: Alongside the funding, Sara Beysolow Nyanti, Resi-
label: BODY

text: dent and Humanitarian Coordinator in South Sudan,
label: BODY

text: put in place decision-making as close to the people
label: BODY

text: of Bentiu as possible. A high-level special task
label: BODY

text: force was established with senior representatives
label: BODY

text: in Bentiu to consult with communities on their pri-
label: BODY

text: orities and to oversee operations. The placement of
label: BODY

text: the task force in Bentiu along with a public project
label: BODY

text: tracker specific to the anticipatory action projects,
label: BODY

text: generated urgency, timely decisions and accounta-
label: BODY

text: bility.4
label: BODY

text: Ahead of the October 2022 floods, partners used
label: BODY

text: the funds to construct and reinforce over 55 kilom-
label: BODY

text: eters of dykes to protect vital access roads, homes
label: BODY

text: and the airstrip. These dykes would prove to be
label: BODY

text: critical, preventing 100,000 people from having to
label: BODY

text: be evacuated and further displaced, even as IDP
label: BODY

text: camps sank below water-level at the peak of the
label: BODY

text: flooding.5 A previously flooded road between Bentiu
label: BODY

text: and Mayom junction was reopened, providing a key
label: BODY

text: supply route that increased the volume of supplies
label: BODY

text: and was estimated to be four times cheaper than
label: BODY

text: having to fly in supplies. Protection of the airstrip al-
label: BODY

text: lowed humanitarian operations to continue through-
label: BODY

text: out the rainy season — a lifeline for the people of
label: BODY

text: Bentiu.
label: BODY

text: Flood waters surrounding Bentiu camp, protected by dykes (October
label: BODY

text: 2022). Credit: UNICEF/Dara Johnston
label: BODY

text: Early investments in latrines, water treatment sites,
label: BODY

text: and cholera vaccine campaigns helped to avert a
label: BODY

text: public health emergency, with the country able to
label: BODY

text: maintain a case fatality rate from cholera of less
label: BODY

text: than 1 percent.6
label: BODY

text: Cash transfers to over 1,000 female-headed house-
label: BODY

text: holds, the majority of whom had at least one family
label: BODY

text: member who was elderly or with a mobility im-
label: BODY

text: pairment, enabled them to reinforce their shelters.
label: BODY

text: Before the floods, at least 93 percent of households
label: BODY

text: reported water entered their shelter when it rained.
label: BODY

text: After making the investment in their shelters, this
label: BODY

text: decreased to 42 percent in one camp and less than
label: BODY

text: 12 percent in the other two camps at the height of
label: BODY

text: the rainy season.7
label: BODY

text: The early allocation of CERF and SSHF funds was
label: BODY

text: catalytic. It rang the alarm bell, mobilizing earlier
label: BODY

text: funding from donors and action from humanitarian
label: BODY

text: partners.8
label: BODY

text: 6 OCHA, CERF Allocation Report on The Use of Funds and Achieved Results - South Sudan Rapid Response for Flood, 2022.
label: BODY

text: 7 International Security Development Center, Impacts of Early Action Support on lives and livelihoods in South Sudan: The Life in Bentiu Study, 2023.
label: BODY

text: 8 OCHA, CERF Allocation Report on The Use of Funds and Achieved Results - South Sudan Rapid Response for Flood, 2022.
label: BODY

text: 9 E. Easton-Calabria, Acting in Advance of Flooding: Early Action in South Sudan, A Feinstein International Center Brief, 2023.
label: BODY

text: “On the whole the money that
label: BODY

text: came in helped quite a bit with
label: BODY

text: mitigation for flooding...
label: BODY

text: Other locations in the camp set
label: BODY

text: up dike committees and trained
label: BODY

text: people immediately. Materials
label: BODY

text: were bought, and tools, and
label: BODY

text: people were able to use the tools
label: BODY

text: to reduce flooding in their sites.”
label: BODY

text: – UNHCR informant9
label: BODY

text: Road recovery: dewatering in process after dike breach along the UNMISS-Rubkona Road 2022. Credit: IOM/Joshua Kanyara
label: BODY

text: The take-away
label: HH1

text: This example from South Sudan demonstrates that
label: BODY

text: in protracted crises and conflict settings, where
label: BODY

text: forecasting data is often less reliable, it is still
label: BODY

text: possible for the humanitarian community to take
label: BODY

text: anticipatory action based on risk and vulnerability.
label: BODY

text: Anticipatory action may work best when there
label: BODY

text: is a framework with a pre-agreed trigger for pre-
label: BODY

text: arranged funding and activities. But sometimes
label: BODY

text: there is not enough time, data, or access to develop
label: BODY

text: such a framework. South Sudan shows this should
label: BODY

text: not stop humanitarians from acting to mitigate the
label: BODY

text: impact ahead of an expected shock. Anticipatory
label: BODY

text: principles can be taken and adapted to context-
label: BODY

text: appropriate programmes.
label: BODY

text: South Sudan also illustrates that continuous
label: BODY

text: learning and improvement is a bedrock for
label: BODY

text: innovation.
label: BODY

text: As of 2 January 2024, OCHA has facilitated
label: BODY

text: collective anticipatory action pilots in 19 countries
label: BODY

text: over three years, releasing some $90 million in
label: BODY

text: funding.
label: BODY

text: “The pilots helped the humanitarian community
label: BODY

text: to learn what works and what doesn’t. They
label: BODY

text: contributed to a mind shift in the humanitarian
label: BODY

text: community, creating a higher level of understanding
label: BODY

text: and acceptance for acting ahead of a predictable
label: BODY

text: or forecasted shock. Senior leaders and donors
label: BODY

text: trust the analysis provided by the Centre and
label: BODY

text: the pilots have given them more confidence to
label: BODY

text: make decisions and fund based on risk,” said
label: BODY

text: Lisa Doughten, Director of OCHA’s Financing and
label: BODY

text: Partnership Division.
label: BODY

text: OCHA continues to facilitate coordinated
label: BODY

text: anticipatory action and has expanded its portfolio
label: BODY

text: of pre-arranged funding to more than $100 million
label: BODY

text: in 15 countries for storms, floods, droughts and
label: BODY

text: cholera.
label: BODY

text: A man checks the water at a surface water treatment system (SWAT) water point for displaced people at Bentiu IDP site A in Bentiu town. The water
label: BODY

text: point is run by IOM serves over 15,000 IDPs in the area. Credit: OCHA/Sarah Waisna
label: BODY

text: CERF is also inviting applications for funding
label: BODY

text: anticipatory action to get ahead of predictable
label: BODY

text: humanitarian impacts of El-Niño-driven climate
label: BODY

text: emergencies.“With an overstretched global system,
label: BODY

text: scaling up anticipatory action remains a top priority
label: BODY

text: for OCHA. This involves advancing analysis on
label: BODY

text: the approach and the related opportunity costs,”
label: BODY

text: said Joyce Msuya, Assistant Secretary-General for
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Affairs and Deputy Emergency Relief
label: BODY

text: Coordinator.
label: BODY

text: OCHA’s Centre for Humanitarian Data is also build-
label: BODY

text: ing on valuable lessons from South Sudan, expand-
label: BODY

text: ing its work on risk analysis to support early action
label: BODY

text: in other contexts.
label: BODY

text: To translate technical information into actionable in-
label: BODY

text: formation for humanitarians, the Centre is expand-
label: BODY

text: ing its work on flood anticipatory action. In partner-
label: BODY

text: ship with Google’s Flood Forecasting Initiative, the
label: BODY

text: Centre is piloting flood early warning across the
label: BODY

text: Niger and Benue river systems to provide automat-
label: BODY

text: ic alerts to decision makers when flood levels are
label: BODY

text: forecasted or observed to rise.
label: BODY

text: By linking analysis to decision makers and funding
label: BODY

text: — like the CERF and implementing partners — OCHA
label: BODY

text: 10 E. Easton-Calabria, Acting in Advance of Flooding: Early Action in South Sudan, A Feinstein International Center Brief, 2023.
label: BODY

text: aims to continue to mobilize pre-arranged financing
label: BODY

text: and resources for anticipatory or early action.
label: BODY

text: Overall, the humanitarian community considers the
label: BODY

text: pilot in South Sudan a success, but with an acute
label: BODY

text: awareness that anticipatory action by itself will
label: BODY

text: never be enough.
label: BODY

text: By the end of the 2022 rainy season in South Sudan,
label: BODY

text: several dykes had burst and homes that had been
label: BODY

text: temporarily repaired were beginning to leak again.
label: BODY

text: There is an urgent need for longer-term disaster risk
label: BODY

text: reduction and development to support the people
label: BODY

text: of South Sudan to endure these increasingly severe
label: BODY

text: climatic events.
label: BODY

text: As observed by one humanitarian partner: “What
label: BODY

text: we’re doing is mitigating the worst humanitarian im-
label: BODY

text: pact for people. But if we don’t have a real climate
label: BODY

text: adaptation programme, where we really look at in-
label: BODY

text: frastructure, roads, dykes, and longer-term areas to
label: BODY

text: protect, like water systems reinforced, we will con-
label: BODY

text: tinue to have massive humanitarian consequences…
label: BODY

text: Our action is meant to be limited in time, but here
label: BODY

text: [in South Sudan] it is the only action taken.”10
label: BODY

text: For the people in Bentiu, that action was critical.
label: BODY

text: IOM team construct new dykes in Bentiu Jedit, Bentiu town in Rubkona Country. The construction work is funded by the Central Emergency Response
label: BODY

text: Fund. Credit: OCHA/Sarah Waisna
